content.body:
Should it be called an operator? It‚Äôs not like it evaluates into an expression by itself‚Äîit‚Äôs kind of more like spread syntax, right?
‚ÄúInterpolation syntax‚Äù, maybe‚Ä¶
content.formatted_body:
Should it be called an operator? It‚Äôs not like it evaluates into an expression by itself‚Äîit‚Äôs kind of more like spread syntax, right?
‚ÄúInterpolation syntax‚Äù, maybe‚Ä¶

content.body: I‚Äôm just thinking about that sentence on the MDN chart of operators that says, ‚ÄúThe spread operator is not in this list because it is not an operator,‚Äù and wondering if inconsistently saying ‚Äúinterpolation operator‚Äù might confuse learners.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence#table
Interpolation whatever-we-call-it wouldn‚Äôt belong on this operator chart, either.
(I do like and appreciate the word ‚Äúinterpolation‚Äù much more than ‚Äúpin‚Äù, for what it‚Äôs worth.)
"the spread operator is not an operator" seems like a dubious statement
like, it may be true according to some strict technical definition, but I'm not sure it's true by anyone's *pragmatic* definition
content.formatted_body: like, it may be true according to some strict technical definition, but I'm not sure it's true by anyone's pragmatic definition

content.body: spread is definitely not an operator, because it doesn‚Äôt work anywhere in expression position
content.formatted_body: spread is definitely not an operator, because it doesn‚Äôt work anywhere in expression position

content.body: similarly yes, I‚Äôd call the ${} ‚Äúplaceholder syntax‚Äù (cc TabAtkins)
or ‚Äúinterpolation placeholder syntax‚Äù, i suppose, to disambiguate from pipeline
(I like ‚Äúinterpolation syntax‚Äù more than ‚Äúplaceholder syntax‚Äù, for what it‚Äôs worth. ‚ÄúPlaceholder syntax‚Äù makes me think of the pipe operator and PFA syntax, haha.)
Yes.
i also prefer the name ‚Äúinterpoliterals‚Äù over template literals too, as long as we‚Äôre naming things :-p
I don't think operators have to be usable in any context to be reasonably called that? My definition is relatively broad.
Spread is def an operator, to me. ${} is as much as operator as () is
yeah, that's pretty much what I was alluding to with "pragmatic definition"
as far as people's mental models are concerned, how they reason about how the language works, it certainly seems to be an operator
Yeah I agree with you
even if it may not meet certain strict technical definitions of one, and may not be one implementation-wise
that definitely does not match my mental model of how languages work
operators are things which turn values into other values
neither spread nor `${}` is an operator in that sense
content.formatted_body: neither spread nor ${} is an operator in that sense

content.body:
> <@tabatkins:matrix.org> I don't think operators have to be usable in any context to be reasonably called that? My definition is relatively broad.

We don‚Äôt have to be prescriptive on how people in general use the word, but since this is the official language explainer and ‚Äúsyntax‚Äù in this case is more precise than ‚Äúoperator‚Äù, then we might as well use the more precise word.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @tabatkins:matrix.org
I don't think operators have to be usable in any context to be reasonably called that? My definition is relatively broad.
We don‚Äôt have to be prescriptive on how people in general use the word, but since this is the official language explainer and ‚Äúsyntax‚Äù in this case is more precise than ‚Äúoperator‚Äù, then we might as well use the more precise word.
